title: Billy Connolly says Parkinson's makes him drool in emotional health update
text:

Billy Connolly has said Parkinson's is now making him drool as he gave an emotional update about his health.

The Scottish comedian, 76, was diagnosed with the disease, in which parts of the brain become progressively damaged, six years ago

He explained that Parkinson's "gives you a new thing" to deal every so often as it progresses, and he's also had trouble with his balance and hearing.

Speaking to Chris Evans on the Virgin Radio Breakfast Show , Billy said: "I've stopped performing because of my Parkinson's disease and I've stopped touring.

"I may perform at some other point but I have no plans to. And I'm quite happy taking my medicine and getting along with it.

(Image: Getty Images)

"I've started to drool which is a new one on me. This disease it gives you a new thing every now and again that you have to deal with and drooling is my latest.

"I walk unsteadily and my hearing is going and it's bizarre that bits of me are fallen off but it's interesting."

Billy admitted that he doesn't know how Parkinson's would affect him on stage now.

He continued: "It would affect my performance. I don't think the way I used to, I don't think at the same speed as I used to.

(Image: Getty Images)

"And because I don't need to. I don't really know if the performance bit has gone because I have to get into the performance mode to see that. I'd have to walk onto the stage and I've never done that.

"And steadily more symptoms come and it's incurable. It's not going to end.

"As a matter of fact I had a Russian doctor in New York who said you realize this is an incurable disease.

(Image: Getty Images)

"And I said you got to get a grip of yourself, stop calling it an incurable disease say we have yet to find the cure. Give the guy a light in the tunnel. Incurable is such an awful thing to say to somebody."

Billy previously said he can no longer sleep in the same bed as wife Pamela Stephenson because Parkinson’s causes him disturbed nights.

"I sleep like a wild animal," he said. "Laughing and singing or having fights. Pamela has to sleep in another bed."
